The court order has been criticised by several groups including the Office of the President, and it has reignited debate on the VFA, which President Duterte originally wanted to abrogate earlier this year, but the abrogation was postponed due to the pandemic. On 7 September, President Duterte granted the US marine an absolute pardon amid widespread criticism, rendering moot legal challenges to the early release and triggering several protests over the issue. The military and police began to immediately implement the stricter and more expansive quarantine rules under the so-called Enhanced Community Quarantine, setting up checkpoints between provinces and prohibiting most forms of domestic land, sea and air travel. Classes, most government work and most private work were suspended, social distancing measures were implemented, and most people were instructed to stay in their houses under penalty of law. On 1 April 2020, Duterte announced that the military and police are authorized to shoot those who violate lockdown measures and challenge law enforcement officials. The Philippine National Police later downplayed the president's remarks and said they would not immediately shoot quarantine violators. notes: Agreement: On 11 February 2020, the Philippine government formally served the United States a notice of termination of the Visiting Forces Agreement, starting a 180-day transition period after which time the agreement will cease to be in force. Location coded to Manila (Metro Manila, National Capital Region). The agreement, signed in 1999, is the legal basis for joint military exercises between the Philippines and the United States. On 2 June 2020, the Philippine government suspended for six months the VFA termination process. The Philippine military and the US welcomed the move, though the president's spokesperson clarified that the suspension does not mean the termination is being reversed. On 11 November 2020, the Philippine government suspended for yet another six months the VFA termination process.

In 2016, the mayor (then vice mayor) was included in President Rodrigo Duterte's list of politicians alleged to be involved in the illegal drug trade. This led to his arrest then. The mayor was also investigated in the same year for a possible connection to the September 2016 bombing of a night market in Davao City.

source: Rappler; HRW; Manila Bulletin; Amnesty International
notes: On 10 February 2020, the government moved to shut down ABS CBN, the Philippines' largest broadcaster, by filing a petition at the Supreme Court in Manila challenging the validity of the media company's operating franchise. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has often been critical of what it perceived as biased journalism from ABS CBN and other media outlets. The Solicitor General's move came even as ABS CBN's operating franchise was set to expire on 30 March 2020, with Duterte threatening to direct his allies in Congress to block the franchise's renewal. This new development attracted widespread condemnation from journalist and left-wing groups and brought about a number of demonstrations. The office of the president denied that it had a hand in the Solicitor General's actions.

source: Philippine Daily Inquirer; Manila Bulletin; CNN; Manila Standard; Philippine Star
notes: On 24 December 2019, a vice mayor belonging to the powerful Ampatuan clan was wounded while his two companions were killed during an attack by unidentified assailants in Barangay Poblacion, Shariff Aguak, Maguindanao. The vice mayor had previously served as prosecution witness during the trial on the recently adjudicated Ampatuan Massacre, which happened in Ampatuan, Maguindanao on 23 November 2009 and left 58 fatalities. The masterminds of the Ampatuan Massacre - including key members of the Ampatuan family - as well as around 40 others were convicted for crimes related to the massacre in December 2019.

source: Cebu Daily News; Philippine Daily Inquirer; Manila Times; Abante; Rappler

actor1: CPP-NPA-NDF: Communist Party of the Philippines-New People's Army-National Democratic Front
notes: On 22 December 2019, upon confirmation from the Office of President Rodrigo Duterte in Manila, the government of the Philippines agreed to a reciprocal Christmas season ceasefire with Communist rebels. The Communist Party of the Philippines had earlier announced the ceasefire through its political wing, the National Democratic Front, in a directive to the New People's Army, and this was to take effect upon a reciprocal announcement from the government. The ceasefire is in effect from 23 December 2019 to 7 January 2020. The president's office also announced that it had ordered the reconstitution of the government peace panel to negotiate with the Communist rebels, in a bid to restart the peace talks. The previous peace talks between the government and the Communist rebels were scrapped last November 2017.

The secretary of the Department of the Interior and Local Government and the National Security Adviser later claimed that the two militants were out on a mission to assassinate the president and other top government officials, though the Communist Party of the Philippines, under which the NPA operates, denied this. The NPA does not normally operate in urban areas, given its Maoist strategy of a rural-based protracted people's war.

That massacre saw 58 fatalities, including 32 media workers. The demonstrators called for justice and demanded a guilty verdict on the massacre's masterminds. During the demonstration, the police confiscated a mural brought by the demonstrators depicting media workers fighting impunity, as they said the mural could trigger a commotion. However, the confiscation instead led to a tense confrontation between the demonstrators and the police. [size=no report]

On 19 December 2019, the masterminds of the November 2009 Ampatuan massacre - including key members of the influential Ampatuan family - as well as around 40 others were convicted for crimes related to the killings by a special court in Camp Bagong Diwa, Taguig. The verdict was deemed a partial victory by several quarters, from journalist groups to victims' relatives, though some key acquittals left some dissatisfied. Given that around 80 suspects remain at large, there are also worries about future violence and acts of retribution in relation to the convictions. The Ampatuan Massacre happened in Ampatuan, Maguindanao on 23 November 2009 and resulted in 58 fatalities, including 32 media workers.

Prior to Robredo's appointment, Duterte had said he would give the so-called drug czar position to Robredo for a couple of months, in which time she would have full powers over the drug war. Robredo's allies in the opposition cautioned her against taking the post, saying she was being set up for failure and that she would be made a scapegoat, but she ultimately took the post, saying she would use the opportunity to put an end to what she called senseless drug war killings.

notes: On 6 November 2019, top drug war critic Vice President Leni Robredo, during a press conference at her office in Quezon City, formally accepted President Rodrigo Duterte's appointment of her as co-chair of the Inter-Agency Committee on Anti-Illegal Drugs (ICAD), a position she would share with the director-general of the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA). The development came a day after the president's appointment of Robredo was officially announced in Manila, following days of heated exchanges between their two camps, where the president dared the vice president to do better than the administration in the implementation of the drug war. In their preceding tit-for-tat, Duterte had said he would give the 'drug czar' position to Robredo for a couple of months, in which time she would have 'full powers' over the drug war. Robredo's allies in the opposition cautioned her against taking the post, saying she was being set up for failure and that she would be made a scapegoat, but she ultimately took the post, saying she would use the opportunity to put an end to the 'senseless' drug war killings. Robredo's appointment papers set 30 June 2022 as the end of her new post's term.

On 6 November 2019, the Bacolod City Prosecutor's Office ordered the release of 31 of the 42 adults who were part of the 56 arrested by the police in Bacolod City, Negros Occidental on 31 October. The 56 individuals were affiliated with different red-tagged organizations and were arrested in simultaneous police operations across Bacolod City on the said date. The Prosecutor's Office found no sufficient basis for the arrest of the 31, who were reportedly merely present at the raided offices when the police operations took place.

assoc_actor_1: KARAPATAN: Alliance for the Advancement of People's Rights

The arrests had been carried out on charges of illegal possession of firearms and explosives, though the organizations concerned said that the evidence was planted. The arrests were defended by authorities as a legitimate operation based on arrest warrants issued by the said Quezon City judge, but were condemned by national and international organizations as a crackdown on leftist groups. Another November 5 raid targeting the office of a red-tagged organization in Manila, which led to the arrest of three more individuals, was also carried out on the basis of a warrant issued by the same judge. The arrests were carried out by the Philippine National Police's Criminal Investigation and Detection Group in coordination with the army, Joint Task Force Negros, and the provincial police. The arrested individuals belonged to organizations that have often been red-tagged by the military. The arrests were carried out on charges of illegal possession of firearms and explosives, though the organizations concerned said that the evidence was planted. The arrests, while defended by authorities as a legitimate operation with the necessary arrest warrants, were described as a crackdown on leftist groups and were condemned by various national and international organizations, such as the organizations' umbrella alliance BAYAN and independent organizations like Amnesty International. A US citizen was also one of the arrested, leading the US labor union she is part of to call for her release.
